questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with progressive memory decline and difficulty performing daily tasks. Neuroimaging shows significant atrophy in the medial temporal lobe, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals high levels of certain neurotoxic oligomers. Which of the following statements regarding the pathology and pathophysiology of this patient’s condition is false?

choices.text: Soluble neurotoxic oligomers lead to synapse loss.
Neurofibrillary tangles contain hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
Plaques indicate polymerization of the neurotoxic proteins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased acetylcholine, norepinephrine and serotonin.

 

Explanation:

In Alzheimer's disease, there is a reduction in acetylcholine due to the degeneration of cholinergic neurons.

  • Additionally, norepinephrine and serotonin levels are also typically decreased due to degeneration in the respective areas (locus coeruleus and dorsal raphe).

 

Pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s Disease:

  • Self-aggregation of amyloid-beta (Aβ) into soluble low-n oligomers causes synaptotoxicity in Alzheimer's disease. (Option A ruled out)
  • Soluble Aβ is strongly correlated with cortical synapse loss, an early pathological event.
  • Cognitive impairment is a direct consequence of synaptic damage.
  • Further polymerization of Aβ leads to fibril formation and the development of amyloid plaques. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mutations in the APP gene increase metabolism of APP through β-secretase activity.
  • Mutations in presenilin 1 (PS1) and presenilin 2 (PS2) are linked to γ-secretase activity.
  • Aβ also accumulates in cerebral arterioles, leading to cerebral amyloid angiopathy.
  • Aβ contributes to the phosphorylation of tau protein, resulting in neurofibrillary tangles.

 

Pathology:

Macroscopic Pathology
  • Earliest degeneration: Seen in the medial temporal lobe (entorhinal/perirhinal cortex and hippocampus), inferolateral temporal cortex, and nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Amyloid plaques: Formed by amyloid beta (Aβ), proteoglycans, ApoE, α-antichymotrypsin, and other proteins.
  • Amyloid angiopathy: Accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles.

Microscopic Pathology
  • Neuritic plaques: Central core of amyloid surrounded by dystrophic neurites and activated microglia.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs): Composed of abnormally hyperphosphorylated tau protein, which forms paired helical filaments. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tau pathology: Hyperphosphorylated tau compromises microtubule function and leads to neuronal dysfunction.
  • Coexisting pathologies: Often seen with DLB, TDP-43, or vascular pathology.

Neurotransmitters
  • Acetylcholine reduction: Due to degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Noradrenergic and serotonergic depletion: From degeneration in the locus coeruleus (norepinephrine) and dorsal raphe (serotonin).
  • Cognitive deficits: Linked to the reduction of acetylcholine and dysfunction in the cholinergic system.

 

Neurofibrillary tangles

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife due to recent personality changes. She reports that he has become impulsive, shows poor judgment in social situations, and has difficulty planning and organizing tasks. His medical history is significant for a car accident 6 months ago. On examination, he shows emotional lability and perseveration. Which area of the brain is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ventromedial orbitofrontal cortex

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, including impulsivity, poor social judgment, difficulty with planning, emotional lability, and perseveration, are classic signs of frontal lobe syndrome, specifically involving the ventromedial orbitofrontal cortex.

Frontal Lobe Syndrome

Area

Functions

Symptoms when Damaged

Ventromedial Orbitofrontal Cortex
  • Social behavior
  • Impulse control
  • Decision making
  • Emotional regulation
  • Impulsivity
  • Poor social judgment
  • Emotional lability
  • Disinhibition

Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex
  • Working memory
  • Planning
  • Attention
  • Problem-solving
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Poor working memory
  • Reduced motivation (abulia)
  • Perseveration

Anterior Cingulate Cortex
  • Motivation
  • Error detection
  • Emotional processing
  • Apathy
  • Reduced initiative
  • Difficulty with emotional regulation

Broca's Area (Left Frontal Lobe)
  • Speech production
  • Expressive aphasia (non-fluent)

 

  • While temporal lobe damage can cause memory problems and emotional changes, it doesn't typically cause the impulsivity and poor judgment seen in this patient. (Option A)
  • Parietal lobe damage is more associated with spatial awareness problems and sensory integration issues, not the behavioral changes described. (Option B)
  • The occipital lobe is primarily involved in visual processing, and damage here would cause visual deficits, not behavioral changes. (Option C)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by his family due to confusion, difficulty walking, and memory problems. On examination, he is disoriented to time and place, has difficulty recalling recent events, and shows signs of confabulation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Korsakoff syndrome

Explanation:
The patient's history of chronic alcohol use, combined with symptoms of confusion, memory problems (particularly for recent events), and confabulation, is highly suggestive of Korsakoff syndrome.

  • This condition is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often associated with chronic alcoholism.
  • Korsakoff syndrome frequently follows Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is characterized by the classic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion.
  • In this case, the presence of confabulation, memory deficits, and alcohol history makes Korsakoff syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

 

Cause of Confabulation:

Confabulation occurs in several neurological conditions where memory is compromised, including:

  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (thiamine deficiency)
  • Anton syndrome (denial of visual impairment)
  • Traumatic brain injury (TBI)

Amnestic Disorders- Causes

Amnestic Disorder

Cause

Key Features

Korsakoff Syndrome

Thiamine deficiency, often due to chronic alcoholism

• Anterograde and retrograde amnesia

• Confabulation

• Personality changes

• Often follows Wernicke encephalopathy

Transient Global Amnesia

Unknown, possibly related to temporal lobe ischemia

• Sudden onset of anterograde amnesia

• Episodes last 6-24 hours

• Complete recovery is typical

Head Injury-Related Amnesia

Traumatic brain injury

• Retrograde amnesia for events leading up to injury

• Anterograde amnesia post-injury

• Severity correlates with injury severity

Cerebrovascular Disease-Related Amnesia

Infarctions affecting hippocampus or thalamus

• Memory impairment

• Often accompanied by other focal neurological signs

Alcoholic Blackouts

Acute alcohol intoxication

• Inability to remember events during intoxication

• Awareness of memory gap upon sobering

ECT-Related Amnesia

Electroconvulsive therapy

• Retrograde amnesia for minutes before treatment

• Anterograde amnesia after treatment

• Usually resolves within hours to months

 

While Alzheimer's disease can cause memory problems, it typically has a more gradual onset and doesn't present with the acute confusion and confabulation described in this case. (Option A)

This condition is characterized by sudden onset of anterograde amnesia that typically resolves within 24 hours. It doesn't explain the chronic nature of this patient's symptoms or the history of alcohol use. (Option B)

While multiple sclerosis can cause cognitive symptoms, including memory problems, it typically presents with other neurological symptoms and is not associated with chronic alcohol use. (Option D)

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter due to progressive memory loss and confusion over the past year. She has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Donepezil

Explanation:

  • For patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil are the first-line pharmacological treatment.
  • They can help improve cognitive function and activities of daily living.

Management of Dementia and Alzheimer’s

Management Strategy

Details

Pharmacological
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine - used as a transdermal patch, galantamine) for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease
  • Memantine - blocks NMDA glutamate receptors, for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease (Option A)
  • Antidepressants for comorbid depression
  • Antipsychotics (with caution) for severe behavioral disturbances

Non-pharmacological
  • Cognitive stimulation therapy
  • Reality orientation
  • Reminiscence therapy
  • Behavioral management techniques
  • Physical exercise programs

Environmental Modifications
  • Simplify the living environment
  • Use memory aids (e.g., calendars, to-do lists)
  • Ensure adequate lighting
  • Remove potential hazards

Caregiver Support
  • Education about the disease
  • Respite care
  • Support groups
  • Counseling

Newly approved drugs for treatment of early Alzheimer's disease.
  • Aducanumab (Aduhelm) - Monoclonal antibody targeting amyloid-beta plaques.
  • Lecanemab (Leqembi) - Monoclonal antibody targeting soluble amyloid-beta protofibrils, facilitating plaque clearance.
  • Donanemab - Monoclonal antibody targeting amyloid plaques; selectively binds to a modified form of amyloid-beta.
  • While memantine is used in dementia treatment, it's typically reserved for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease, often in combination with a cholinesterase inhibitor. (Option A)
  • Antipsychotics like risperidone are only used cautiously in dementia for severe behavioral disturbances, not as a first-line treatment for cognitive symptoms. (Option C)
  • Antidepressants may be used in dementia patients with comorbid depression, but they're not the primary treatment for cognitive symptoms. (Option D)

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son due to concerns about her memory. The physician decides to administer the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE). Which of the following statements about the MMSE is correct?

choices.text: It was originally designed to identify early stages of dementia
It takes approximately 30 minutes to administer
A score of 23/24 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment
The test protocol and variables are the same for different socio-geographic populations

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A score of 23/24 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment

Explanation:
The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), also known as the Folstein test, is a 30-question assessment of cognitive function. A score of 23 or 24 out of 30 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment including dementia.

Key points about the MMSE include:

  1. It evaluates ORRAL (mnemonic)
  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Recall
  • Attention and concentration
  • Language.
  1. It is widely used and accepted among health professionals and researchers.
  2. The test is brief, usually taking no more than 10 minutes to administer. (Option B)
  3. A score of 23 or 24 out of 30 is traditionally used as a cut-off for suspected cognitive impairment, though this can vary based on population norms.
  4. Scores can be influenced by sociocultural variables, age, and education level, necessitating the development of local standards for each population and setting. (Option D)
  5. The MMSE was not originally designed to identify early stages of dementia or distinguish between different types of dementia. (Option A)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive cognitive decline over the past 6 months. He has difficulty with memory, confusion, and occasional myoclonic jerks. His medical history is unremarkable, but his wife mentions he was an avid hunter who often consumed venison. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Neurocognitive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury
Neurocognitive Disorder due to HIV Infection
Neurocognitive Disorder due to Prion Disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neurocognitive Disorder due to Prion Disease

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of progressive cognitive decline, memory issues, confusion, and myoclonic jerks, along with a history of consuming venison (which can potentially be contaminated with prions causing Chronic Wasting Disease), is most consistent with a prion disease such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

Causes of Neurocognitive Decline

Characteristic

Due to Traumatic Brain Injury

Due to HIV Infection

Due to Prion Disease

History

H/O traumatic brain injury, with associated noncognitive symptoms

HIV diagnosis, Associated cognitive symptoms

Cognitive impairment: Subtle onset, Rapid progression

Key Symptoms
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Amnesia following trauma
  • Confusion/ disorientation
  • Neuroimaging evidence of injury/ Neurologic symptoms
  • Cognitive symptoms associated with HIV infection
  • May include memory issues, attention deficits, and slowed processing speed
  • Rapid cognitive decline
  • Motor symptoms (e.g., myoclonus/ ataxia)
  • Biochemical marker on testing

Onset

Acute, following traumatic event

Gradual, as HIV progresses

Subtle onset, but rapid progression

Course

Can improve, stabilize, or worsen over time

Often fluctuates with HIV treatment and progression

Progressive rapid decline

 

EEG findings in Prion Disease:

  • Triphasic Waves - Repetitive, sharp waves followed by a slower wave. Frequency: 1-2 Hz.
  • Generalized slowing (theta and delta waves). Decreased amplitude of brain waves.
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) may be present.
  • Changes are bilateral and symmetric.
  • Alpha rhythm may be attenuated or absent

Neurocognitive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury (Option A) is incorrect as there is no history of head trauma mentioned, and the onset is described as progressive rather than acute.

Neurocognitive Disorder due to HIV Infection (Option B) is incorrect because there's no mention of HIV diagnosis or risk factors, and the progression is typically not as rapid as described in this case.

Alzheimer's Disease (Option C) is incorrect because the progression is too rapid for typical Alzheimer's, and the presence of myoclonic jerks is more suggestive of prion disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with noticeable cognitive decline. She is diagnosed with Dementia with Lewy Bodies. Which of the following is not a core feature of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systematized delusions

 

Explanation:

While delusions can occur in DLB, systematized delusions (fixed false beliefs that are well organized) are not considered a core feature of the condition, rather are considered a supporting feature.

  • DLB primarily features hallucinations, particularly visual ones, rather than structured delusions.

 

Dementia with Lewy Bodies

  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline sufficient to interfere with social or occupational functioning.
  • Early symptoms may include difficulties with attention, fronto-subcortical skills, and visuospatial ability, rather than prominent memory issues.

 

Clinical Features:

Probable DLB requires two or more core symptoms, while possible DLB requires at least one.

Core Features

Supporting Features
  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (Option B ruled out)
  • Parkinsonian features (e.g., cogwheeling, bradykinesia, resting tremor) (Option D ruled out)
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Repeated falls
  • Syncope
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics
  • Systematized delusions (Option C)
  • Hallucinations in other modalities (e.g., auditory, tactile)

 

Differences in features of LBD and PD:

Feature

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)

Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Onset of Symptoms

Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms appear early; motor symptoms develop later.

Primarily motor symptoms appear first (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors).

Visual Hallucinations

Common and can occur early.

Less common initially; may occur later, often due to treatment.

Fluctuations in Attention

Fluctuations in alertness and attention are characteristic.

Fluctuations are primarily related to medication cycles.

Response to Medications

Poor response to dopaminergic medications; risk of worsening psychiatric symptoms.

Generally improves with dopaminergic medications (e.g., levodopa).

Sleep Disturbances

REM sleep behavior disorder is common and can precede cognitive symptoms.

REM sleep behavior disorder may occur but is primarily linked to motor symptoms.

Progression

Rapid progression of cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Gradual progression of motor symptoms, with cognitive decline developing later.

 

Pathology:

  • Lewy body disease presents clinically similarly to Alzheimer’s disease but is marked by hallucinations, parkinsonian features, and extrapyramidal signs.
  • Lewy bodies, which are abnormal accumulations of α-synuclein aggregates, are found in the cerebral cortex and substantia nigra.
  • In cases where Lewy body pathology coexists with Alzheimer’s, the amygdala is often the only affected region.
  • Patients with Lewy body dementia may exhibit Capgras syndrome (reduplicative paramnesia), highlighting the complex nature of their symptoms.

Lewy bodies

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with noticeable personality changes, including increased impulsivity and a lack of empathy towards his family. He has difficulty regulating his emotions and exhibits hyperorality, often eating unusual food combinations. His cognitive functions related to memory and perception appear preserved. A family history of similar symptoms is noted. Based on the presented symptoms, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pick’s Disease

 

Explanation:

Pick’s Disease is characterized by early personality and behavioral changes, including disinhibition, lack of empathy, and hyperorality, while other cognitive functions remain intact initially.

  • The patient’s age and family history of similar symptoms further support this diagnosis.
  • The behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia aligns closely with the symptoms presented.

 

Frontotemporal Dementia (Pick Disease):

  • Affects frontotemporal regions with atrophy.
  • Involves neuronal loss, gliosis, and Pick bodies (not needed for diagnosis).
  • Accounts for about 5% of irreversible dementias.
  • More common in men, especially with a family history.
  • Early symptoms include personality and behavioral changes; other cognitive functions are preserved.
  • Typically begins before age 75; familial cases may start earlier.
  • Features like hypersexuality and hyperorality are more common than in Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Difficult to distinguish from Alzheimer’s in early stages.

Aspect

Behavioral Variant

Language Variant

Affected

Social cognition/executive function

Language (word finding, naming, grammar, less spontaneous speech)

Spared

Learning/memory/perceptual-motor function

Learning/memory/perceptual-motor function

Associated Symptoms (≥3)
  • Disinhibition
  • Apathy
  • Lack of sympathy/empathy
  • Perseveration/stereotypies
  • Hyperorality/dietary changes

N/A

Probable
  • Evidence of a genetic cause (family history/genetic testing)
  • Neuroimaging evidence of frontal/temporal pathology

Possible

Some but not all the probable criteria met


 

Cause of Dementia

Clinical Features

Alzheimer's Disease
  • Gradual memory loss. Memory impairment is usually the first symptom
  • Difficulty with problem-solving and disorientation
  • Presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles on brain imaging or autopsy
  • Irreversible; progressive neurodegeneration

Vascular Dementia
  • Cognitive decline following a stroke (CT/MRI showing infarcts)
  • Fluctuating abilities
  • Impaired judgment
  • Potentially reversible if acute vascular events are treated promptly

Lewy Body Dementia
  • Hallucinations occurring early - Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity)
  • Fluctuating cognition
  • REM sleep behavior disorder
  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotics
  • Irreversible; symptomatic treatments may help manage symptoms

Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Early onset (often under 65 years)
  • Language difficulties and disinhibition
  • Significant changes in social behavior or personality
  • Irreversible; progressive condition

Alcohol-Related Dementia
  • Memory problems and history of alcohol abuse
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Social withdrawal
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)
  • Potentially reversible with abstinence and nutritional support

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease
  • Rapidly progressive dementia
  • Myoclonus
  • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings
  • Rare, irreversible; rapidly progressive and fatal

Pick's Disease
  • Marked personality changes
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Emotional blunting
  • MRI/CT shows frontal and temporal lobe atrophy
  • Behavioral changes prominent early
  • Irreversible; part of the frontotemporal dementia spectrum

 

Alzheimer’s Disease (Option A): Primarily involves memory impairment and gradual cognitive decline, not prominent personality changes as seen here.

 

Multi-Infarct Dementia (Option B): Characterized by stepwise deterioration due to vascular issues, not marked by the significant behavioral symptoms present in this patient.

 

Lewy Body Dementia (Option C): Features cognitive fluctuations and visual hallucinations, with motor symptoms; the patient's main issues are behavioral, not motor.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension is evaluated for cognitive decline. His family reports that he has had several episodes of confusion and difficulty with problem-solving. Neurological examination reveals evidence of white matter changes on MRI and he has a history of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following features is MOST characteristic of vascular dementia in this patient?

choices.text: Continuous and gradual decline in cognitive function.
Cognitive changes following a stroke only.
Stepwise deterioration in cognitive abilities over time.
Memory loss as the only symptom.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stepwise deterioration in cognitive abilities over time.

 

Explanation:

The stepwise deterioration in cognitive abilities is a hallmark of vascular dementia, particularly as seen in patients with a history of TIAs and small vessel disease, which this patient exhibits.

 

Vascular Dementia:

  • Vascular dementia, previously known as multi-infarct dementia, is caused by multiple areas of cerebral vascular disease.
  • Most common in men, especially those with hypertension or cardiovascular risk factors.
  • Affects small- and medium-sized cerebral vessels, leading to infarctions and parenchymal lesions.
  • Causes of infarctions include arteriosclerotic plaques or thromboemboli from distant sources (e.g., heart valves). (Option B ruled out)
  • Types:
    • Acute onset after strokes
    • Multi-infarct dementia from transient ischemic attacks
    • Subcortical dementia associated with hypertension (white matter injury)
    • Mixed vascular dementia.
  • Typically shows stepwise deterioration, unlike the gradual decline seen in Alzheimer’s disease. (Option A ruled out)
  • Symptoms may include carotid bruits, fundoscopic abnormalities, or enlarged cardiac chambers. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diagnosis requires clinical or laboratory evidence of a vascular cause.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the key difference between twilight state and oneiroid state?

choices.text: The twilight state is characterized by disturbed consciousness with unexpected violent acts, while the oneiroid state involves a more dream-like, less interactive experience.
The oneiroid state features disorientation and confusion, whereas the twilight state is marked by clarity and coherence.
In the twilight state, individuals are typically fully unconscious, while those in the oneiroid the state exhibit fluctuating consciousness
The oneiroid state is primarily associated with external stimuli, while the twilight state is largely independent of environmental factors.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The twilight state is characterized by disturbed consciousness with unexpected violent acts, while the oneiroid state involves a more dream-like, less interactive experience.

 

Explanation:

  • The twilight state is characterized by disturbed consciousness with unexpected violent acts, while the oneroid state involves a more dream-like, less interactive experience.

 

Twilight state:

  • Disturbed consciousness with hallucinations.
  • Onset/end- Abrupt
  • Episodes of unexpected violent acts/ emotional outbursts.
  • Seen in cases of epilepsy, brain tumors, and head injury.

 

Dream-like (oneiroid) state:

  • Impairment of consciousness
  • Dream-like experiences: Vivid, surreal perceptions resembling a dream, often with hallucinations or delusions.
  • Disorientation: Difficulty distinguishing reality from the dream-like mental state.
  • Fluctuating consciousness: Periods of clarity mixed with deep confusion.
  • Detachment: Reduced interaction with the environment, as the individual is absorbed in internal, fantasy-like experiences.

 

Level of Consciousness

Features

Alertness
  • Normal cognitive function
  • Fully awake and aware of the environment
  • Appropriate responses to stimuli
  • Ability to maintain attention.

Lethargy (Somnolence)
  • Drowsy but can be awakened
  • Decreased alertness
  • Slow responses to questions
  • May fall asleep easily
  • Requires external stimulation to maintain wakefulness.

Obtundation
  • Reduced awareness and responsiveness
  • Difficult to arouse
  • Responses are slowed
  • The individual may appear confused or disoriented.

Stupor (Semicoma)
  • Near-unresponsive state;
  • Can only be aroused with vigorous or painful stimuli.
  • With no awareness of the environment.

Coma
  • Unresponsive state
  • Cannot be aroused even with strong stimuli.
  • No voluntary responses
  • Brain activity may still be present at a basic level (reflexes may occur).

 

Other terms related to disturbance with consciousness:

 

Torpor
  • A state of physical and mental inactivity, often due to fatigue or metabolic disturbances.
  • Reduced responsiveness
  • The individual may appear lethargic and is difficult to arouse without significant stimuli.

Twilight
  • A transitional state between alertness and lethargy, characterized by confusion and disorientation.
  • Responses may be variable
  • Onset/end- Abrupt
  • Episodes of unexpected violent acts/ emotional outbursts.
  • The individual may exhibit impaired judgment and perception of reality.

Oneiroid State
  • A dream-like state with vivid hallucinations
  • The individual may be unaware of their surroundings.
  • Experiences of hallucinations or delusions, leading to a distorted perception of reality
  • Unresponsive to external stimuli.



 

The oneiroid state features disorientation and confusion, whereas the twilight state is marked by clarity and coherence (Option B): This is incorrect. Both states can involve confusion, but the clarity typically associated with the twilight state is not accurate.

 

In the twilight state, individuals are typically fully unconscious, while those in the oneiric state exhibit fluctuating consciousness (Option C): The twilight state does not necessarily imply full unconsciousness; rather, individuals may be partially aware but still confused or hallucinatory.

 

The oneiric state is primarily associated with external stimuli, while the twilight state is largely independent of environmental factors (Option D): This is not accurate. Both states can be influenced by external stimuli, but the experience of the oneiric state often resembles a dream in response to both internal and external cues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive memory loss over the past year, along with increasing difficulty in planning and organizing daily tasks. Her family reports that she often misplaces items and struggles to follow conversations. Which of the following genes does NOT cause early-onset of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) APOE gene

 

Explanation:

The patient’s clinical features—progressive memory loss, difficulties in planning and organizing tasks, and issues with conversation—strongly point to a diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease.

  • Given her age and the nature of her symptoms, this suggests early-onset Alzheimer's disease (EOAD).
  • The APOE gene, particularly the ε4 allele, is a key risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) rather than early-onset.

 

Alzheimer’s Disease

  • Cognitive Changes: Starts with memory impairment, progressing to executive function, language, and visuospatial deficits.
  • Recognizable memory loss, with about 50% progressing to Alzheimer’s within four years.
  • Biomarkers can indicate amyloid pathology up to 20 years before symptoms.
  • Late Stage Symptoms: Wandering, loss of judgment, delusions, sleep-wake pattern changes, and parkinsonian features.
  • Typical course lasts 8-10 years, but can range from 1 to 25 years; memory impairment is a key feature.
  • Epidemiology: Seen in females more than males.

 

Genetics:

Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (EOAD)

Late-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD)
  • APP gene (chromosome 21): Associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease (FAD) and Down's syndrome. (Option A ruled out)
  • Presenilin-1 (PSEN-1): Most common cause (40-70%), mean onset at 45 years, rapid progression (6-7 years) (Option B ruled out).
  • Presenilin-2 (PSEN-2): Less common, mean onset at 53 years, slower progression (11 years). (Option D ruled out)
  • Pathogenesis involves mutations that increase Aβ42 levels and amyloid accumulation.
  • APOE gene (chromosome 19) is a key risk factor.
  • ApoE ε4 allele: Increases risk and lowers age of onset (about 10 years per allele).
  • ApoE ε2 allele: May reduce risk.
  • Risk varies by ethnicity; higher in East Asians, lower in Blacks and Hispanics.
  • Polygenic Risk: Additional genes (e.g., CLU, PICALM, CR1) involved, with smaller individual effects. Variants in TREM2 significantly increase AD risk (odds ratios 3-4).

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty concentrating, and irritability over the past several months. His family reports recent weight loss and changes in appetite. On examination, he appears pale, and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Basic laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his cognitive decline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Explanation:

Vitamin B12 deficiency is one of the common reversible causes of dementia.

  • In this case, the patient's cognitive decline, weight loss, and pale appearance, along with findings of macrocytic anemia (e.g., hypersegmented neutrophils), strongly suggest vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • This deficiency can lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms, including memory loss, irritability, and cognitive impairment.
  • The pathophysiology involves the disruption of myelin synthesis and subsequent demyelination, which affects both the central and peripheral nervous systems.

 

Types of Dementia:

Degenerative dementias

  • Alzheimer disease
  • Frontotemporal dementias (e.g., Pick disease)
  • Parkinson disease
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Idiopathic cerebral ferrocalcinosis (Fahr disease)
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Limbic predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy (LATE)

Miscellaneous
  • Huntington disease
  • Wilson disease
  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy
  • Neuroacanthocytosis

Psychiatric
  • Pseudodementia of depression
  • Cognitive decline in late-life schizophrenia

Demyelinating diseases
  • Multiple sclerosis

Cardiac, vascular, and anoxia
  • Infarction (single or multiple or strategic lacunar)
  • Binswanger disease (subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy)
  • Hemodynamic insufficiency (e.g., hypoperfusion or hypoxia)

Physiologic
  • Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Metabolic
  • Vitamin deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate)
  • Endocrinopathies (e.g., hypothyroidism)
  • Chronic metabolic disturbances (e.g., uremia)

Tumor
  • Primary or metastatic (e.g., meningioma or metastatic breast or lung cancer)

Traumatic
  • Dementia pugilistica, posttraumatic dementia
  • Subdural hematoma

Infection
  • Prion diseases (e.g., Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, bovine spongiform encephalitis, Gerstmann–Sträussler syndrome)
  • Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)
  • Syphilis

Drugs and toxins
  • Alcohol
  • Heavy metals
  • Irradiation
  • Cognitive dysfunction due to medications (e.g., anticholinergics)
  • Carbon monoxide

 

Some types of dementia can be attributable to reversible causes, such as metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hypothyroidism), nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12 or folate deficiencies), normal pressure hydrocephalus or dementia syndrome caused by depression.

Dementia is classified based on the brain structures involved into following 2 types:

  1. Cortical Dementia:
    • Involves the cerebral cortex, leading to impairments in memory, language, and higher cognitive functions.
    • Examples: Alzheimer's disease, Frontotemporal dementia).
  2. Subcortical Dementia:
    • Affects deeper brain structures (basal ganglia, thalamus), causing psychomotor slowing, mood changes, and movement disorders.
    • Examples: Parkinson’s disease dementia, Huntington’s disease.

 

Important causes of dementia and their clinical features:

Cause of Dementia

Clinical Features

Alzheimer's Disease
  • Gradual memory loss.
  • Memory impairment is usually the first symptom
  • Difficulty with problem-solving and disorientation
  • Presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles on brain imaging or autopsy
  • Irreversible; progressive neurodegeneration

Vascular Dementia
  • Cognitive decline following a stroke (CT/MRI showing infarcts)
  • Fluctuating abilities
  • Impaired judgment
  • Potentially reversible if acute vascular events are treated promptly

Lewy Body Dementia
  • Hallucinations occurring early - Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (tremors, rigidity)
  • Fluctuating cognition
  • Severe sensitivity to antipsychotics
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Irreversible; symptomatic treatments may help manage symptoms

Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Early onset (often under 65 years)
  • Language difficulties and disinhibition
  • Significant changes in social behavior or personality
  • Irreversible; progressive condition

Alcohol-Related Dementia
  • Memory problems and history of alcohol abuse
  • Difficulty with planning and organization
  • Social withdrawal
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)
  • Potentially reversible with abstinence and nutritional support

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease
  • Rapidly progressive dementia
  • Myoclonus
  • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings
  • Rare, irreversible; rapidly progressive and fatal

Pick's Disease
  • Marked personality changes
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Emotional blunting
  • MRI/CT shows frontal and temporal lobe atrophy
  • Behavioral changes prominent early
  • Irreversible; part of the frontotemporal dementia spectrum

 

Alzheimer's disease (Option A):

  • This is the most common cause of dementia but is not reversible.
  • It is characterized by progressive memory impairment, language difficulties, and visuospatial deficits.
  • Neuropathology involves amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles.

 

Vascular dementia (Option C):

  • This form of dementia results from cerebrovascular disease, often associated with a stepwise decline in cognitive function due to multiple infarcts or small vessel disease.
  • While some modifiable risk factors like hypertension can be controlled, the established dementia is not typically reversible.

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Option D):

  • A rapidly progressive dementia caused by prion disease.
  • It leads to severe neurological deficits, including myoclonus and ataxia, with death typically occurring within a year.
  • It is not reversible.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought in due to progressive memory loss over two years. She frequently forgets recent events, misplaces items, and has become socially withdrawn. Neurological exam shows intact motor function but poor recall after 5 minutes and disorientation to time. Blood work and imaging are unremarkable. Which of the following is not a typical feature of this condition?

choices.text: Rapid onset and fluctuation of symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rapid onset and fluctuation of symptoms

 

Explanation:

  • Rapid onset and fluctuation of symptoms is NOT typical of dementia but is more characteristic of delirium, which is an acute, fluctuating disturbance in attention and cognition.

 

Dementia/Major Neurocognitive Disorder is characterized by a progressive decline in cognitive abilities, (Option A) which involves the impairment of at least one (usually two or more) cognitive domains such as:

  • Memory (Option B)
  • Attention
  • Executive function
  • Language
  • Perceptual-motor abilities
  • Social cognition

 

Etiology:

Dementia can be caused by several underlying conditions, including:

  • Alzheimer’s Disease
  • Vascular Dementia
  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies
  • Frontotemporal Dementia
  • Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
  • HIV-associated Dementia
  • Prion Diseases
  • Parkinson’s Disease
  • Huntington’s Disease

 

Epidemiology: With the aging population, dementia has become increasingly common, especially in older adults.

  • Approximately 5% of individuals over the age of 65 suffer from moderate to severe dementia
  • The prevalence rises sharply in the elderly, affecting 20-40% of individuals over the age of 85
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause, alone or in combination with other etiologies, accounts for about 70% to 80% of dementias.
  • Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) is characterized by the same neuropathologic changes as Alzheimer disease, with neurofibrillary tangles and plaques, plus Lewy bodies in cortical and brain stem regions, and accounts for about 15% to 35% of dementias.
  • Vascular disease, both small vessel and large vessel disease affecting cortical or subcortical regions accounts for about 5% to 20% of dementias.
  • It associated with risk factors like hypertension and cerebrovascular disease
  • Other causes of dementia, such as those related to alcohol, head trauma, and movement disorders like Huntington’s and Parkinson’s diseases, each represent around 1-5% of cases

 

Symptoms:

Dementia presents with a broad range of cognitive and behavioral symptoms, which may vary based on the underlying cause but generally include:

Memory Impairment
  • Early signs include difficulty recalling recent events, conversations, or tasks (e.g., forgetting appointments, misplacing items).
  • Over time, even long-term memories may be lost, and patients may forget personal details like their birthplace or the names of close relatives.

Impaired Attention and Executive Functioning
  • Patients struggle with tasks requiring planning, decision-making, and problem-solving.
  • This impairment affects their ability to perform activities of daily living, such as managing finances, cooking, or following a schedule.

Disorientation
  • Patients may become disoriented to time, place, or person.
  • For example, they may forget where they are or be unable to find their way back to their room after using the bathroom.

Language Deficits (Aphasia)
  • Difficulty in finding the right words, naming objects, or following a conversation is common, especially in cortical dementias like Alzheimer's disease.
  • As the condition progresses, speech may become nonsensical or fragmented.

Personality and Behavioral Changes (Option D)
  • Some patients become socially withdrawn, while others exhibit agitation, irritability, or aggression.
  • Disinhibition and inappropriate behavior can occur.
  • Patients with psychotic symptoms may develop paranoid delusions or hallucinations. (Most common is the delusion of persecution).

Mood and Emotional Changes
  • Depression and anxiety are common.
  • Patients may also experience emotional lability, swinging between laughing and crying without obvious triggers.

Motor Symptoms
  • Motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia can accompany cognitive decline in certain types of dementia, like Parkinson’s disease or Lewy body dementia.
  • Neurologic findings such as seizures or primitive reflexes (e.g., grasp reflex) may appear in some patients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female is brought by her daughter, who reports that her mother has been progressively forgetting names, events, and sometimes even familiar faces over the last year. Recently, she misplaced household items and became suspicious of neighbors, accusing them of stealing. The patient is oriented to time and place but cannot recall what she had for breakfast. Her mood appears stable, and she does not report hearing voices or seeing things. There is no history of psychiatric illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dementia

 

Explanation:

  • Dementia is characterized by progressive cognitive decline, with memory impairment (especially recent memory) and sometimes paranoia or delusions.
  • Dementia is characterized by:  
  1. Cognitive impairment (4 A's Amnesia, Aphasia, Agnosia, Apraxia)
  2. Behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD)
  3. Focal neurological deficits
  • In this case, the patient has had progressive memory loss over a year and has become suspicious, consistent with the cognitive and behavioral changes seen in dementia​.

 

Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Schizophrenia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Gradual (months to years)

Gradual (late adolescence/adulthood)

Course

Fluctuates (worse at night)

Progressive, stable day-to-day

Chronic, can have relapses

Attention

Impaired

Initially normal, impaired later

Usually intact

Orientation

Disoriented

Mostly intact until late stages

Intact

Hallucinations

Visual, tactile (common)

Rare

Auditory (common)

Memory

Short-term impaired

Long-term impaired

Intact (except in psychosis)

Consciousness

Fluctuating

Normal until late stages

Normal

 

Schizophrenia (Option B) is less likely because the onset of schizophrenia is typically earlier in life (late adolescence to adulthood). Although paranoia is a common feature of schizophrenia, the absence of auditory hallucinations and the late onset of symptoms makes schizophrenia an unlikely diagnosis​.

 

Delirium (Option C) is an acute condition, associated with fluctuating levels of consciousness and disorientation, which are not present in this case​.

 

Major Depressive Disorder (Option D) with psychotic features could cause paranoia, but the absence of other classic depressive symptoms such as a low mood and loss of interest makes this diagnosis less likely​.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia. Three days into the hospital stay, he becomes acutely confused, disoriented to time and place, and exhibits fluctuating levels of consciousness. The patient is agitated, pulling at his IV lines, and experiencing visual hallucinations. His family reports he was mentally alert prior to admission. The patient's vital signs show fever and tachycardia. His medication list includes antibiotics, antihypertensives, and metformin. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Rule out metabolic and infectious causes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rule out metabolic and infectious causes

 

Explanation:

This patient presents with typical clinical features of delirium, including acute onset, fluctuating course, disorientation, hallucinations, and altered attention.

  • Delirium is a common condition in hospitalized elderly patients and is often secondary to underlying medical issues such as infections, metabolic imbalances, or medication side effects.
  • The primary step in managing delirium is to identify and treat the underlying cause, which in this case could include pneumonia or other metabolic disturbances.

 

Assessment:

Delirium is assessed primarily through clinical observation and mental status examinations.

Specific tools for assessment:

  • The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is commonly used to diagnose delirium based on four features: acute onset, fluctuating course, inattention, and disorganized thinking or altered consciousness.
  • The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) can help document cognitive impairments and establish a baseline to monitor changes over time​.

 

Physical and Neurological Examination:

Common findings include:

  • Fever (suggestive of infection), tachycardia (metabolic disturbances or hyperthyroidism), or bradycardia (intracranial pressure, hypothyroidism).
  • Neurological signs: Tremor, asterixis, incoordination, nystagmus, and reflex abnormalities (e.g., Babinski sign) may point toward neurological causes.

 

Laboratory and Imaging Workup: Laboratory tests help to rule out metabolic causes:

  • Blood chemistries (electrolytes, renal and hepatic function, glucose levels)
  • Complete blood count (to detect infection or anemia)
  • Thyroid function tests
  • Toxicology screens (for substance-induced delirium)
  • If indicated, imaging studies such as CT or MRI are performed to rule out structural brain lesions. EEG may be done to differentiate delirium from other psychiatric conditions, as it often shows diffuse slowing in delirium​.

 

Treatment:

The treatment of delirium has two major components: addressing the underlying cause and providing symptomatic relief.

  1. Treating the underlying cause:
    • Identifying and reversing the underlying cause is the most important step. Causes can range from infections (such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections) to metabolic imbalances, dehydration, or drug toxicity.
  2. Supportive care:
    • Patients should be in a safe and calm environment, free from both sensory deprivation and overstimulation. Measures include:
      • Repeated orientation to time, place, and person
      • Having familiar objects or people around (e.g., family, familiar pictures)
      • Adequate lighting, presence of clocks and calendars​
  3. Pharmacological Treatment: Pharmacotherapy is primarily reserved for managing severe symptoms such as agitation, psychosis, or extreme distress.
    • Antipsychotics - Haloperidol (commonly used drug), Olanzapine - for managing psychosis and agitation.
    • Sodium valproate or dexmedetomidine - for agitation when antipsychotics fail or are contraindicated.
    • Benzodiazepines - DOC in Alcohol Withdrawal (Delirium tremens)
    • Insomnia - Benzodiazepines worsen confusion in non-alcohol-related delirium so non-pharmacologic strategies like sleep hygiene practices are preferred.

 

Administer antipsychotic medication immediately (Option A): They are not the first-line treatment and should only be used after the underlying cause of delirium has been identified.

 

Discontinue all medications (Option B): Abruptly stopping all medications can cause harm.

  • A more measured approach is required where medications with a potential role in causing delirium (e.g., anticholinergics, opioids) are reviewed and possibly adjusted or discontinued after careful consideration.

 

Start long-term benzodiazepine therapy (Option C): Benzodiazepines are contraindicated in most forms of delirium except for those caused by alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal.

  • They can worsen confusion and increase the risk of falls in elderly patients.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia. On the second day of hospitalization, he becomes confused, agitated, and disoriented to time and place. His family reports that he was cognitively intact before admission. He is unable to focus on simple tasks and frequently hallucinates. His symptoms fluctuate throughout the day, worsening at night. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Delirium

 

Explanation:

Delirium is a life-threatening but potentially reversible disorder that involves an acute decline in attention, awareness, and cognition, often triggered by medical conditions, medications, or substance withdrawal.

 

Neurochemical and Neuroanatomical Basis of Delirium:

  • Decreased Ach
  • The major neuroanatomical area involved is the reticular formation which regulates attention and arousal
  • The major pathway implicated is the dorsal tegmental pathway, which projects from the mesencephalic reticular formation to the tectum and thalamus.

 

Clinical Features and Clinical Diagnosis of Delirium:

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset of altered consciousness and cognitive impairment, with a hallmark feature being impaired attention. It often presents with abnormalities of mood, perception, and behavior.

 

Common clinical features include:

  • Fluctuating course: Symptoms tend to wax and wane, and the patient may have periods of lucidity followed by severe cognitive disorganization.
  • Impaired attention: Patients have difficulty focusing, sustaining, or shifting attention.
  • Cognitive dysfunctions: These include disorientation (especially to time and place), memory impairment, and disturbances in language and perception.
  • Motor disturbances: Hyperactive or Hypoactive
  • Mood and behavioral changes: Abnormalities in mood (such as agitation or lethargy) and perception (hallucinations or delusions) are frequent.
  • Sleep disturbances: Decreased sleep, reversal of sleep-wake cycle.
  • Neurological signs: Tremors, asterixis, nystagmus, and incoordination may be observed.
  • Sundowning - symptoms worsen at night.
  • Course:
    • Acute: hours to days
    • Persistent: weeks to months

 

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, with a focus on history and mental status examination.

  • The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) can be utilized to assess cognitive impairment and establish a baseline to monitor the patient's clinical course.
  • The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is used for diagnosing delirium that involves the presence of 
  • Acute onset and fluctuating course,
  • Inattention, and
  • Disorganized thinking
  • Altered level of consciousness.

A positive diagnosis is made if features 1 and 2 are present, along with either feature 3 or feature 4.

  • Additionally, an EEG may show diffuse slowing, which helps distinguish delirium from psychiatric disorders like depression or psychosis.

Feature

Delirium (Option A)

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, may occur in advanced stages

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages


Schizophrenia (Option B) is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and negative symptoms such as flat affect. It does not present with an acute onset or fluctuating course of cognitive impairment, and attention is generally preserved outside of psychotic episodes.

 

Major depressive disorder with psychotic features (Option D): This condition can include psychosis, such as hallucinations or delusions, but the primary feature is a depressed mood lasting for at least two weeks. The cognitive disturbances in depression are more static and do not exhibit the fluctuating, acute course seen in delirium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man came to OPD with complaints of impaired consciousness, confusion, inattention, disorganized thinking, and visual hallucination, with symptoms more at night. Which clinical feature is most characteristic of this psychiatric condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fluctuating levels of consciousness

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of impaired consciousness, confusion, inattention, disorganized thinking, and visual hallucinations—with symptoms worsening at night—are highly suggestive of delirium.

Fluctuating levels of consciousness are a hallmark of delirium. Patients often exhibit periods of confusion and altered awareness that can change throughout the day. It develops quickly and has a fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning)

 

  • Delirium is an acute decline in both the level of consciousness and cognition with particular impairment in attention.
  • A life-threatening yet potentially reversible disorder of the central nervous system (CNS), delirium often involves perceptual disturbances, abnormal psychomotor activity, and sleep cycle impairment.
  • Abnormalities of mood, perception, and behavior are common psychiatric symptoms.
  • Tremor, asterixis, nystagmus, incoordination, and urinary incontinence are common neurologic symptoms.
  • Classically, delirium has a sudden onset (hours or days), a brief and fluctuating course, and rapid improvement when we can identify the cause and eliminate it, but each of these characteristic features can vary in individual patients.

 

Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, may occur in advanced stages

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages

 

Predisposing factors:

  • Elderly age
  • History of substance abuse or alcohol withdrawal (Delirium Tremens)
  • Association with a chronic medical illness
  • History of surgical illness
  • Post-operative period
  • Sensory deprivation
  • Poly-pharmacy


 

Etiologies:

Drugs
  • Alcohol
  • Sedatives
  • Antidepressants

Endocrinal
  • Hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism
  • Hypopituitarism/hyperpituitarism

Liver
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

Infections
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonia

Renal
  • Uremic Encephalopathy

Intracranial
  • Epilepsy
  • Tumors
  • Injury

Others
  • Heat
  • Sleep deprivation

Metabolic
  • Hypoxia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Electrolyte imbalance


 

Type of Delirium

Causes

Hypoactive Delirium
  • Electrolyte imbalances, hypoglycemia, hepatic encephalopathy, uremia
  • Urinary tract infections, pneumonia, sepsis
  • Stroke, traumatic brain injury, dementia
  • Sedatives (benzodiazepines, opioids), anticholinergics, psychotropic medications
  • Heart failure, respiratory failure, dehydration

Hyperactive Delirium
  • Alcohol withdrawal, withdrawal from benzodiazepines or sedatives
  • Stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines), hallucinogens (LSD, PCP)
  • Hyperthyroidism, fever or infection (sepsis)
  • Traumatic brain injury, encephalitis
  • Anticholinergics, stimulants

Mixed Delirium
  • Acute severe infections (pneumonia, sepsis), post-surgical states
  • Mixed electrolyte imbalances, liver or renal failure
  • Combination of sedatives and stimulants.
  • Dementia with acute exacerbation, delirium superimposed on chronic cognitive decline

 

Gradual onset of cognitive decline (Option A): This feature is more typical of dementia rather than delirium, which usually presents with a more acute change in mental status.

 

Stable and coherent thought processes (Option C): This is characteristic of normal cognition or dementia, not delirium, where thought processes are often disorganized and incoherent.

 

Fixed and focused attention (Option D): In delirium, attention is typically impaired, making this option incorrect. Patients may have difficulty sustaining attention or may become easily distracted.
